https://jenkins.openbmc.org/job/ci-repository/97537/ : SUCCESS
We should be able to read the current state before the polling. Have you looked into read line status in constructor?

We can, but I see that it makes this type stand out from the others because they should all be able to call readSensor() as their own way to read. Moreover, I think let them 3 all use timer polling will make pollSensorStatus() to be implemented by the base class instead of being overriden by the 3 and also get rid of the need to read the intial state.

I'm not sure if there will be other types coming that prefer another method to poll over using timer. Do you suggest that I should leave it like that and just read the initial state for this type in its constructor?

I do think for system implemented the intrusion with GPIO and supports interrupt. Take advantage of the hardware capability makes the code more efficient.

> make pollSensorStatus() to be implemented by the base class instead of being overriden by the 3

I don't understand why it can not be only overridden by GPIOSensor type

You're right about the hw ability we should enlist. Updated to just initially update value for GPIO type and let pollSensorStatus be overridden by the GPIO class only, other classes will directly use the definition in the base class.
Done
The change in GPIO reading from event to polling looks good for me. It is the sensor, not the signal, therefore, we don't have to monitor the GPIO's events.
Please remove commented code
Done
Please add a precise error message which is easily understandable
This one is from the previous commit so I didn't change it here.
autoRearm : can you name it which is understandable? What will this value signify?

This one is from the previous commit also (https://github.com/openbmc/dbus-sensors/commit/b318dcaeaf0e847b6f0e2bc9365873ebe4e5dabd) which adds the Rearm property. Can you please refer to that commit which tells more about the definition. To sum up, it shows whether we have to rearm the sensor after intrusion or let it rearm automatically when the chassis cover is closed again.
What was tested on Ampere's Mt Mitchell, please provide more information here.
ACK.
Friendly ping... The two patches in this chain have been here for a while, can someone please help give them some reviews or let them be proceeded? Thanks.
Adding Jagpal, as he seems to have an interest in GPIO detection within dbus-sensors.
Move this to be after line 406 to avoid potential race condition where the value changes between the get_value() and event_get_fd()
Agreed. Updated.

Hi @Chau, I think you should change the method to read GPIO's status from event to polling reading. I suggest that b/c some GPIO can be the i2c peripheral device (like pca9555), they can not generate event when the GPIO's status changed. Beside that, we can unify the reading method of I2C/GPIO/Intrusion-Driver to polling.

I used to sync three classes to use the same polling function just for code simplicity, but the maintainer suggested to enlist the hardware ability and I think that makes sense as the intrusion just happens once in a while so polling can be expensive. Moreover, will the chassis intrusion button be connected to a pin to a i2c device instead of a real GPIO pin? I'm OK with both methods because I'm not experienced, so I need more feedbacks about this.

I would suggest not to remove event support solely because a specific device doesn't support it. The code is already in place, and it's beneficial to keep it. Instead, consider implementing a meson-based option that enables polling for devices that don't support events. This way, events can remain the default path while still accommodating devices with limited capabilities. Would suggest running this by maintainers to get their feedback.
Does implementation handles the case - if there is a GPIO status change between initial read and gpio polling start? If not, do you think it will be better to change the order to start polling first?

Do you foresee any specific issues with overriding the start() method? The implementation above appears to be correct, but it requires a closer look to understand what's being done. In general i don't have any specific preferences.  

> I believe no event can jump in before pollSensorStatus() completes, so it won't cause Read-after-write hazard, right?

Looks fine to me.

> Do you foresee any specific issues with overriding the start() method? The implementation above appears to be correct, but it requires a closer look to understand what's being done. In general i don't have any specific preferences.

No, I see no issue, just wanted it to be neat. You are right, this can cause confusion. I updated to let gpio class override the start() function.
